title: Autumn Leaves
source: Traditional jazz standard — simplified lead sheet arrangement

musicalLanguage.description: The quintessential jazz standard for learning ii-V-I progressions. The A section descends through the circle of fifths in G major (Cm7-F7-BbM7-EbM7), then the B section mirrors the same motion in E minor. Every jazz musician knows this tune — it's the 'Hello World' of jazz harmony.
musicalLanguage.structure: AABA — 32 bars (this excerpt: first A section, 8 bars)
keyMoments: Bars 1-2: Cm7 to F7 — the ii-V in Bb major. Feel the pull toward resolution.
Bars 3-4: BbMaj7 to EbMaj7 — arrival, then the IV chord adds color
Bars 5-8: Am7b5 to D7 to Gm — the ii-V-i in G minor. The tune 'turns the corner' here.
teachingGoals: ii-V-I voice leading — the smoothest path between chords
Swing eighth notes — long-short feel, not straight
Left-hand shell voicings: root + 7th (or 3rd + 7th) for each chord
styleTips: Swing feel — triplet-based eighths, emphasis on beats 2 and 4
Melody in the right hand should be legato and vocal
Left hand: keep shell voicings in the middle register, not too low

measures.teachingNote: Cm7 chord — the ii of Bb. Left hand plays root + 7th shell voicing.
F7 — the V of Bb. Notice how the melody descends stepwise.
BbMaj7 — resolution! The ii-V has arrived. Let it ring.
EbMaj7 — the IV chord. It adds warmth before the tune shifts to minor.
Am7b5 — half-diminished. This is the ii of G minor. Feel the mood darken.
D7 — the V of G minor. The F# in this chord pulls hard toward G.
Gm — minor resolution. The whole section was a journey through the circle of fifths.
Let the G ring out. In performance, this is where you'd start improvising.
